items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high autumn and winter rainfall and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Ashley Green, Chesham.

Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in Chesham such as the Vale Road area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater.  

We expect levels to remain high over the coming weeks in response to the high winter rainfall. Low lying lands and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding.   

Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.  We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 31st March or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Burn from Southgate and Waterden to Burnham Thorpe
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is still likely today, Monday 29th March, and for the rest of this week. River and groundwater levels remain high and are expected to remain high for the next few weeks. The forecast is for dry conditions today and tomorrow. Take care on riverside footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and levels closely, and will update this message by 10am on Monday 5th April.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond will be 4.88 mAOD at 05:30 on 31/03/21 and 4.71 mAOD at 17:45 on 31/03/21.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are peaking. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 75 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next 5 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 21:00 on 31/03/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high autumn and winter rainfall, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom.     
Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom areas are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater.  
We expect levels to remain high over the coming weeks in response to the high winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of groundwater flooding.   
Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 31st March or as the situation changes.

Groundwater levels have responded to high autumn and winter rainfall, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill close to Flamstead.

Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater.  

We expect levels to remain high over the coming weeks in response to the high winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of groundwater flooding.   

Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 31st March or as the situation changes.

Groundwater levels at the Snailwell Borehole are steady but remain high. Consequently there is an increased risk of groundwater flooding. We expect flooding to affect areas of Newmarket at risk of groundwater flooding, including the High Street. There is potential for further rainfall this week, therefore there is a risk that the groundwater levels will remain high over the next few weeks. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water. This message is updated weekly due to the slow reaction and will be updated Wednesday 31 March, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Little Stour, Nailbourne, River Wingham, River Stour

items.message: The Nailbourne & Little Stour have been flowing since mid-January. Levels peaked in February and are now slowly in recession. However, some flooding of low-lying land, gardens and roads is still occurring at various locations including North Elham, Barham, Patrixbourne, Bridge and Littlebourne. Some roads remain closed at fording points. The internal flooding of residential properties is not expected. The Littlebourne Flood Relief Channel is in operation and temporary defences operate in Barham. Please avoid driving in floodwater as bow waves from vehicles may cause property flooding. Environment Agency operatives are ensuring the free flow of water. We are monitoring the situation and co-ordinating efforts with local authorities and community leaders. Levels are gradually reducing but this alert will remain in force until more roads are opened to traffic. This message will be updated by Friday 2 April or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Marham and Setchey Bridge river gauges. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland remains possible. We expect flooding to affect the River Nar from Litcham to South Lynn. No rainfall is forecast over the next few days, however we expect the river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Wednesday 31 March, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels at our observation borehole at Northfield Farm in the Great Shefford area have declined following limited rainfall over the last few weeks. Groundwater levels are still high and close to a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater if we receive heavy rainfall. 

We expect levels to remain high, but continue to slowly fall over the coming week. Water levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message Tuesday (06/04/2021), or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Derwent Water lake level remains high as a result of persistent heavy rainfall over the last few days.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Seatoller, Stonethwaite, Rosthwaite, Grange-in-Borrowdale and Derwent Water shoreline areas. High river and lake levels are possible on the River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck, Watendlath Beck, Derwent Water and their tributaries.    


No further rainfall is forecast and whilst lake levels have started to recede they will remain high over the coming days. 


We are closely monitoring the situation.    
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.   


This message will be updated tomorrow morning 31/03/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
Windermere Lake level remains high as a result of persistent heavy rainfall over the last few days.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Langdale, Grasmere, Ambleside, Troutbeck, Windermere, Hawkshead, Rusland Valley, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cartmel, Cark and Winster Valley areas. High river and lake levels are possible on Great Langdale Beck, River Brathay, River Rothay, Trout Beck, Mill Beck, Cunsey Beck, Windermere Lake, Rusland Pool, River Eea, River Winster and their tributaries.    


No further rainfall is forecast and whilst lake levels have started to recede they will remain high over the coming days. 


We are closely monitoring the situation.    
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.   


This message will be updated tomorrow morning 31/03/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater remains high.  Over the last 7 days, there has been a slight increase in level in Appleshaw and Hatherden, as groundwater responded to rain which was recorded between 10th and 13th March. In Kimpton, the level continues to fall. From today (Wednesday 24/03/21) until next week, small amounts of rain are forecast, with heavy showers expected on Friday (26/03/21). In Hatherden and Appleshaw, groundwater has not yet lowered for a period of several successive days.  Rain this week could therefore cause levels to rise (perhaps by another 10 cm or so). Whilst it is unlikely that rain this week will cause impacts, groundwater is only marginally below a level where historically, a small  number of cellars have been affected in Hatherden and Appleshaw. We would therefore like communities to remain prepared, just over the next few weeks. We will update this message by 12:00 on Wednesday 31st March 2021.

River levels are high but are beginning to fall at the Pooley Bridge river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall over the last few days.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Bampton, Patterdale, Glenridding, Dockray, Pooley Bridge, Dacre, Eamont Bridge and Penrith areas. High river and lake levels are possible on the River Lowther, Haweswater Beck, Goldrill Beck, Grisedale Beck, Glenridding Beck, Aira Beck, Ullswater, River Eamont, Dacre Beck, Thacka Beck and their tributaries.    


No further rainfall is forecast and we expect lake and river levels to fall. 


We are closely monitoring the situation.    
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads which may be flooded.   


This message will be updated tomorrow morning 31/03/2021, or as the situation changes.

High spring tides are forecast on Wednesday and there is the possibility of some minor overtopping of sea defences along the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir.  Forecast high water is 09:30 on 31/03/21 with a level of 6.84 mAOD and a Force 2 East South Easterly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point gauge and mAOD is height above average sea level. Minor flooding to roads and farmland is possible at the peak tide and one to two hours either side of the high tide. For more detail please refer to local tide tables. 
Our incident response staff will monitor the situation and will close coastal flood gates. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads.

River and lake levels remain high at the Lodore gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall over the last few days.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site      


No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect water levels to remain high over the coming days. 


We are closely monitoring the situation.    
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near lakes and rivers and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads which may be flooded.   


This message will be updated tomorrow morning 31/03/2021, or as the situation changes.

River Cocker, River Marron, River Derwent

items.message: River levels remain high at Ouse Bridge river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall over the last two days. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Buttermere, Lorton Valley, Cockermouth, Branthwaite, Bridgefoot, Camerton, Barepot and Workington areas. High river levels are possible on the River Cocker, Whit Beck, River Derwent, River Marron, Lostrigg Beck and their tributaries. No further rainfall is forecast and levels will continue to recede. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 31/03/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: The Flood Alert for the Tidal River Ouse remains in force, as river levels remain high following recent heavy rainfall. The River Ouse in York is currently 2.5m  and at Naburn is 2.3m and is continuing to fall steadily.  Flooding of low lying footpaths, roads, and farmland remains possible. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days. Our incident response staff continue to closely monitor the forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning 31/03/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: The Flood Alert for the Upper Ouse remains in force, as river levels remain high following recent heavy rainfall. The River Ouse in York is currently 2.5m and continuing to fall steadily. Flooding of low lying property, footpaths, and roads, remains possible. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days. Our incident response staff continue to closely monitor the forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning 31/03/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Minehead, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea and Uphill to Kingston Seymour
items.message:
High spring tides are forecast on Wednesday and there is the possibility of some minor overtopping of sea defences and limited flooding of coastal and tidal areas.  Forecast high water is 09:30 on 31/03/21 with a level of 6.84 mAOD and a Force 2 East South Easterly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point gauge and mAOD is height above average sea level. Minor flooding to roads and farmland is possible at the peak tide and one to two hours either side of the high tide. For more detail please refer to local tide tables. 
Our incident response staff will monitor the situation and will close coastal flood gates. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides on Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning. High water at Ilfracombe is at 8:30pm on Tuesday evening and at 8:45am on Wednesday morning. Times of high water will vary along the coast.  There may be minor overtopping of sea defences at exposed locations.

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; the forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe is 5.06mAOD on Tuesday evening and 5.16mAOD on Wednesday morning.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
High still water level is expected to affect the foreshore as a result of high spring tides and strong winds.  Tides will be at their highest between 12:00 and 16:00 today, 31/03/21. Flooding to properties/roads and farmland is expected/possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying land, roads and coastal paths at Fleetwood Docks and Marina, Fleetwood Marsh Nature Park, Barnaby's Sands, Burn Naze, Sower Carr, Hambleton, Stannah, Trunnah, Thornton, Skippool and Little Eccleston.   
Coastal conditions should ease for the 01/04/21 high tide at 01:30. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.     
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  
This message will be updated  in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

A Flood Alert remains in place as a result of high spring tides. Flooding of low lying coastal paths, roads and farmland is possible tonight between 23:15 and 03:15, 31/03/21. It is forecast that the high tide tomorrow lunchtime 31/03/21 will also reach the Flood Alert criteria. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land, roads and coastal paths at Roosebeck, South Ulverston, Canal Foot, Crake estuary, Rusland Valley, Leven estuary, Eea estuary, Flookburgh, East Plain Farm, Grange-over-Sands, Meathop, Kent estuary, Milnthorpe, B5282 coast road, Sandside and Arnside. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths and roads along the coastline. The high tide this evening forecast to cross the Flood Alert threshold and will be updated tomorrow, 31/03/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
A large tidal surge is expected with possible overtopping and onshore flooding as a result of high water levels. The time and date of the first forecast high water is 09:00 on 31/03/2021. The forecast tide level is 7.86 m AOD. The forecast wind strength and direction is Force 2 in a north north west direction. The time and date of the second forecast high water is 21:15 on 31/03/2021. The forecast tide level is 7.53 m AOD. The forecast wind strength and direction is Force 2 in a west north west direction. There is a possibility of flooding for the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham, and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehamption Park, including Pill and Shirehampton.

Our operation teams are closing flood gates in the Pill and Shirehampton area. Be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. 
Please note all tide times are in local time and are using the 24 hour clock and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth.

Over the next few days high tides are expected to be higher than usual as a result of spring high tides. Based on the current forecast the next high tide at midnight 31/03/2021 is not expected to reach the flood alert threshold. Flooding of low lying land, roads and farmland is possible during the midday tide tomorrow, 31/03/21. We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land in the following places: Fiddlers Ferry between 14:30 and 15:15 BST, with a peak of 6.36m, Eastford Road between 14:45  and 15:30 BST, with a peak of 6.51m, and Arpley Bridge between 15:00 and 15:45 BST, with a peak of 6.57m. It is possible river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue flood warnings if required. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation. We will issue further alerts and update this message as necessary.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. Tide levels will remain higher than normal over the coming days due to spring tides which peak today, Tuesday 30th March. The forecast is dry for the next few days. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from East Cley to Kelling Hard, including Salthouse
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. Tide levels will remain higher than normal over the coming days due to spring tides which peak today, Tuesday 30th March. The forecast is dry for the next few days. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

This message contains gauge information for Newport and Avonmouth Gauge. River levels are forecast to rise at the Avonmouth and Newport gauges as a result of high tides. Flooding is possible on the high tide on Tuesday evening 30/03/21 and Wednesday morning 31/03/21. Flooding could affect roads including garages & footpaths in Brockweir and Elmdale, Chepstow. 
Predicted peaks: Newport: 7.0 to 7.2 metres at 21:30 on Tuesday evening 30/03/21 and 7.1 to 7.3 metres at 09:45 on Wednesday morning 31/03/21
Avonmouth: 13.9 to 14.1 metres at 21:45 on Tuesday evening 30/03/21 and 14.0 to 14.1 metres at 10:00 on Wednesday morning 31/03/21. The period of high tides is expected for the next 2 days. We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 31/03/21, or if the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 1:15am and 3:15am tomorrow morning, Wednesday 31st March. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.72 mAODN at 2.15am tomorrow, which is 0.05m above tide tables, wind Force 3, Southerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor the situation, and will reissue this message for any subsequent tides if required.

High spring tides are forecast on Wednesday and there is the possibility of some minor overtopping of sea defences along the coastline between Gullhouse Point and Marine Parade.  Forecast high water is 10:00 on 31/03/21 with a level of 7.86 mAOD and a Force 2 North North Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth gauge and mAOD is height above average sea level. Minor flooding to roads and farmland is possible at the peak tide and one to two hours either side of the high tide. For more detail please refer to local tide tables. 
Our incident response staff will monitor the situation and will close coastal flood gates. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads.
